Athena

ATHENA: A Framework based on Diverse Weak Defenses for Building Adversarial Defense

by Ying Meng*, Jianhai Su, Jason O'Kane, Pooyan Jamshidi*

Introduction

ATHENA is a flexible and extensible framework for building generic yet effective defense against adversarial attacks. ATHENA is based on ensemble of many diverse weak defenses (WDs). Each WD is a machine learning classifier (e.g., DNN, SVM) that first applies a transformation on the original input and then produces an output for the transformed input. Given an input, an ensemble first collects the predicted outputs from all WDs and then determines the final output for the input by some ensemble strategy such as majority voting or averaging the outputs. By ensembling diverse transformations, ATHENA provides a tradeoff space, where one can achieve a higher robust by adding more weak defenses to the ensemble or achieve lower overhead and cost by removing some weak defenses.

The ATHENA framework consists of 2 phases: (i) a training phase, where WDs, each is associated with a transformation, are trained independently; and (ii) a test phase.

Publication

  1. Ying Meng, Jianhai Su, Jason O'Kane, Pooyan Jamshidi. ATHENA: A Framework based on Diverse Weak Defenses for Building Adversarial Defense , arxiv 2001.00308, 2020.

Code

https://github.com/softsys4ai/athena

Talks

    Ensembles of Many Diverse Weak Defenses can be Strong: Defending Deep Neural Networks Against Adversarial Attacks from Pooyan Jamshidi

Future Works

Some future works based on Athena:

  • Adversarial detector
  • Automatically optimize weak defenses
  • Representation learning in adversarial ML
  • Defending against both sensitive and invariance adversarial perturbation
